title: 113_hr2230
content: The "Track It to Prevent It Act" includes sections on improved climate assessments, service-wide 360 assessments, health welfare inspections, and reviews of security and diversity management. It also authorizes appropriations. Congress finds that in fiscal year 2012, there were 3,374 reported sexual assault cases in the Armed Forces, with a 6% increase from the previous year. Additionally, approximately 26,000 members made anonymous reports of sexual assault, showing a significant rise from the previous year. A high percentage of female and male members who experienced unwanted sexual contact also faced sexual harassment. Moreover, a majority of those who reported unwanted sexual contact perceived some form of retaliation. In fiscal year 2012, 52% of individuals who experienced unwanted sexual contact also faced sexual harassment. Additionally, 62% of those individuals perceived some form of retaliation. Commanders must comply with climate assessments to create a safe environment. Improved performance assessments and reporting by commanders can help identify trends in harmful behavior. Reasons for not reporting incidents include fear of inaction and negative impact on military career. According to a report, members often choose not to report sexual harassment and assault incidents due to concerns that nothing will be done about it and fear of negative impacts on their military career. Commanders' tolerance or ignorance of such misconduct perpetuates a culture that hinders change. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines "sexual harassment" and "sexual assault" in accordance with Department of Defense directives. The Secretary of Defense must ensure that command climate assessment results are shared with relevant commanders and higher levels of command. Each military department must include a designated form in performance evaluations for senior commanders to indicate if required assessments were conducted. Failure to conduct assessments will impact performance evaluations and promotion considerations. The Inspector General of the Department of Defense will develop a tracking system for command climate assessments. The Inspector General of the Department of Defense will develop a system to track commanders' conduct of command climate assessments. Unit commanders must gather climate assessments and create compliance reports including concerns, leadership perception data, and strategic plans for addressing issues. The Secretary of Defense mandates the inclusion of reprimands, counseling statements, and actions related to sexual harassment or assault in performance evaluations to increase visibility, identify trends of misconduct, and prevent the transfer of offenders. Additionally, service-wide 360 assessments are required. SEC. 6. Service-wide 360 assessments will be adopted by each military department, modeled after the Department of the Army's MSAF Program. Individual counseling will be included in the performance evaluation process. SEC. 7. Health welfare inspections will be conducted monthly to ensure security, readiness, and discipline, with results provided to commanders. The Secretary of each military department conducts monthly health welfare inspections to maintain security, readiness, and discipline in all Armed Forces units. Results are shared with commanders. Additionally, there is a review of the security of military installations, including barracks and multi-family residences. The Secretary of Defense will review security measures on military installations, focusing on barracks and multi-family residences to ensure the safety of Armed Forces members and their dependents. The review will identify security gaps and assess the feasibility of 24-hour electronic monitoring or security personnel at entry points. A report with study results, including cost estimates to address security gaps and provide 24-hour monitoring, must be submitted to Congress within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Defense will submit a report to Congress within 90 days of the Act's enactment, detailing the costs to address security gaps and provide 24-hour security monitoring on military installations. The Secretary of Defense will conduct a review of the Office of Diversity Management and Equal Opportunity to evaluate resource gaps, the role in sexual harassment cases, and collaboration with the Sexual Assault Prevention and Response Office. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal year 2014 to carry out this Act.
